string.value: Nuremburg Laws
Formalizing the racial policies of its leaders Germany passes laws that limits German citizenship to non-Jews of Germanic blood.
Gestapo Law
The Gestapo, the German secret police force, gains supreme law enforcement powers throughout Germany.
Germany reoccupies the Rhineland
Germany marches a small number of troops into the demilitarized Rhineland, in violation of the Versailles Treaty.
Italy annexes Ethiopia
After seven months of battle, Italy defeats and annexes Ethiopia.
Romany sent to Dachau
Germany sends Romany to the concentration camp at Dachau, outside of Munich.
Rebellion in Spain
Soldiers stage a coup against the Spanish government, launching the Spanish Civil War.
German Air Support to Spanish Nationalists
Germany sends combat aircraft to aid the Nationalists in Spain. Over time, this would grow into the Condor Legion, a full-fledged German air force operating in support of the Nationalist cause.
French Non-Intervention in the Spanish Civil War
The French government announces a policy of non-intervention in the Spanish Civil War. France follows by closing the border to volunteers wanting to fight in Spain.
German Conscription
To expand the size of its military, Germany begins drafting soldiers for two-year terms.
Japan Issues Secret Demands
Tokyo demands that China allow Japan to "advise" the Chinese government. If China refuses Japanese control, Japan threatens invasion.
Belgium Cancels Alliance with France
Fearing a new European war, Belgium withdraws from its military pact with France and claims neutral status.
Jews Banned from Teaching in Germany
Germany bans Jews from teaching in public or private schools.
Rome-Berlin Axis
Germany and Italy form an alliance, primarily directed against Britain and France.
Germany and Italy Recognize Nationalist Spain
Berlin and Rome recognize the Nationalist military regime as the official Spanish government.
Anti-Comintern Pact
Germany, Japan, and Italy agree to oppose international Communism. This pact implicitly threatens the Soviet Union.
Italian Forces in Spain
Italian forces begin fighting for the Nationalists in Spain's Civil War.
United States' Third Neutrality Act
In response to the Spanish Civil War, the United States extends its policy of strict neutrality in international wars to include civil conflicts.
USSR "Purges" Senior Generals
Driven by paranoia, the Soviet leader begins imprisoning and executing Red Army generals believed to be disloyal.
Marco Polo Bridge Incident
Japanese and Chinese forces fight near the border of Japanese-occupied Manchuria. This skirmish unofficially begins the Sino-Japanese war.
Buchenwald Opens
The Buchenwald concentration camp takes in its first prisoners as the German program of discrimination against Jews picks up steam.
Japan Captures Peiping (Beijing)
Continuing its drive into China, the Japanese Army captures the ancient Chinese capital city.
US Arms Embargo on China and Japan
The United States, in accordance with its neutrality laws, declares an embargo on shipping weapons to China or Japan in US ships.
German War Aims

In an address to his military, the German leader spells out what Germany must have: living space and racial security. This means war to expand Germany's borders and to purge the society of unwanted races, namely Jews.
Rape of Nanking (Nanjing)

After a difficult campaign, Japan captures the city of Nanking (Nanjing). Taking out their frustrations on the civilian population, Japanese soldiers commit unspeakable atrocities in their occupation of the city.
Defeat of the Ludlow Resolution
In a close vote, the House of Representatives defeat a resolution that would have required a national referendum to declare war (except in cases of invasion).
Austrian Plebiscite
In the face of German efforts to dominate Austria, Austrian leaders announce a plebiscite to determine the nation's future, and specifically to reaffirm its independence.
Germany Annexes Austria
Angered by the Austrian plebiscite, Germany sends its army into Austria and seizes control of the country.
France and Britain Promise to Support Czechoslovakia
In response to the Austrian annexation, Britain and France declare their determination to protect Czechoslovakia from German aggression.
Anglo-Italian Pact
To reduce tensions in the Mediterranean, Britain negotiates a treaty recognizing Italian control of Ethiopia and normalizing relations throughout the region.
Identity Cards Required in Germany
Jews over 15 are required to keep identity cards and display them on demand.
Mauthausen Opens
On the heels of the Aeschylus of Austria, Germany opens its first concentration camp in the new German territories.
Germany Demands Sudeten Self-Determination

Germany demands self-determination for German-speakers living in the Czechoslovakian Sudetenland. This sets off widespread disorders in the region, and prompts Britain and France to call for a personal meeting with the German fuehrer (leader).
Czechoslovakia Accepts German Demands

Britain and France propose that Czechoslovakia allow Germany to occupy all Sudeten regions that are more than 50% German-speaking . Abandoned by its allies, Czechoslovakia is forced to agree to German demands.
New Sudeten Demands
Germany rejects the Anglo-French proposal, and demands all the Sudetenland. If this is not met, Germany threatens to invade Czechoslovakia, beginning on September 30.
German Jews Banned from the Law
Following the bans on teaching and medicine, Germany bans Jews from practicing law.
Munich Conference

Committed to avoiding war, French and British leaders meet with the German Fuhrer. Italy attends this conference as well. All four powers accept the Munich agreement, which satisfies every Germany demand for Czechoslovakia.
Germany Occupies the Sudetenland
Pursuant to the Munich accord, German forces occupy the Sudeten region of Czechoslovakia. The Czech government resigns.
Deportation of Polish-German Jews
Germany deports 17,000 Jews of Polish origin, but Poland refuses to accept them. The Jews remain in a no-mans land between the two nations.

In an outpouring of racism driven by government propaganda and other factors, German citizens engage in the largest pogrom against Jews in recent memory. Shops are destroyed, people beaten and killed, and many Jews are imprisoned.
Germany Fines Jews for Kristallnacht
In a touch of savage irony, Germany fines the victims of the Kristallnacht riots one billion marks for the damage caused by their attackers.
Japan Repudiates US Open Door Policy
Responding to US protests that Japan had violated the "open door" policy, where all nations have equal rights to commerce and trade in China, Japan declares the policy null and void.
Aryanization of Jewish Businesses
Germany demands that all businesses be owned only by Aryans (non-Jews of "proper" racial origin), forcing mass sell-offs by Jewish owners.
Franco-German Pact
Germany and France agree to respect each other's borders and resolve all disputes peacefully.
Britain, France Recognize Nationalist Spain
Following the Nationalist occupation of Barcelona and capture of Catalonia, the British and French governments recognize the Nationalists as the victors in the Spanish Civil War.
Germany Occupies Remainder of Czechoslovakia
Seizing Bohemia and Moravia, Germany completes the destruction of Czechoslovakia as an independent state. Germany establishes Slovakia as a puppet nation.
Germany Annexes Memel
Germany pressures Lithuania into ceding the Baltic fortress city of Memel in return for German security guarantees.
Official End to Spanish Civil War
With the surrender of the last Republican strongholds, the nearly three year long conflict in Spain comes to a close.
Britain and France Guarantee Polish Security
Spurred into action by the continued aggressiveness of Germany foreign policy, Britain and France extend security guarantees to Poland, pledging to support it against any German attack.
Italy occupies Albania
Continuing its quest for power and glory, the Italian government invades and conquers the Balkan nation of Albania, on the Adriatic coast.
America requests non-aggression pledges from Italy, Germany
In return for disarmament talks and trade negotiations, the United States asks Germany and Italy to guarantee no further attacks on European or Mediterranean nations. The offer is rebuffed.
Moscow proposes alliance with London, Paris

In an effort to build a true coalition against German aggression, the USSR proposes alliance with Britain and France. Facing domestic fears of Communism, neither nation is willing to agree to such a treaty.
Britain introduces conscription
Belatedly beginning to prepare for an increasingly likely war, Britain abandons its traditional volunteer army and begins conscription in order to build up a larger, more capable ground force.
Germany renounces Anglo-German Naval Treaty
Accusing Britain of attempting to encircle Germany, the German government backs out of the 1935 naval treaty with the United Kingdom.
Ravensbruck opens
The only major concentration camp expressly for women opens with the arrival of the first prisoners.
Rome-Berlin Axis finalized
Berlin and Rome culminate their relationship with a full military and political alliance.
Japanese blockade British in China

Angry over alleged British support for Chinese nationalists, Japan blocks the British treaty port of Tianjin, China. This cuts off British and French trade through the port and heats up the animosity between Tokyo and the West.
Polish Crisis begins
With tensions running high, pro-German citizens of Danzig push for "deliverance" by Germany. Border clashes, rising tensions, and heated rhetoric push both nations towards war.
German-Soviet Trade Agreement
Though ideologically opposed, Germany and the USSR have great need for each other's trade. This agreement shocks Europe but gives both nations the resources they need for military preparation.
German-Soviet Non-Aggression Pact

In a stunning failure for British and French diplomacy, the USSR, which had initially sought alliance with the West, signed a non-aggression treaty with Germany. This pact also pledged neutrality if the other party went to war. Secret provisions of the agreement divided up all of Eastern Europe between Moscow and Berlin.
Anglo-Polish Assistance Pact
After granting the British Prime Minister extraordinary powers, the British also make a new commitment to Polish security in an effort to deter German aggression.
Germany invades Poland
Poland refuses to meet German territorial demands. In response, nearly two million German soldiers pour into Poland.
Britain, France declare war on Germany

True to their word, London and Paris declare war on Germany in support of Poland, though there is little that either nation can do militarily. At the same time, Belgium and Spain reiterate their neutrality.
United States affirms Neutrality
Following its Neutrality Laws, the United States declares its neutrality in the growing European war.
Jewish property confiscated
Germany orders all Jewish commercial property transferred to "Aryan" owners.
Soviet-Japanese Armistice
Ending four months of sporadic and sometimes intense combat, Japan and the USSR sign an armistice, freeing both countries to focus on more crucial conflicts.
USSR invades Poland
Having resolved the Japanese threat, and keeping with the secret portions of the agreement with Germany, the USSR invades Poland.
Berlin Conference on Polish Jews
In a meeting in Berlin, German security leaders agree on a plan to round up Polish Jews for better control and to facilitate future efforts at emigration or eradication.
Warsaw surrenders
Overwhelmed by the dual assault of Germany and the USSR, the Polish capital surrenders.
First Jewish Ghetto formed
Acting on the plans laid down in September, Germany forms the first formal Polish "ghetto" for Jews, in the town of Piotrkow.
US begins A-Bomb work
In a meeting with top scientists, the American President lays the groundwork for a project to build an atomic weapon.
US allows cash sales to belligerents
Modifying its laws against selling arms to belligerents, the US begins allowing "cash and carry" arms sales. In practice, this meant sales to Britain and France only.
Jews Forced to Wear Star of David
Germany orders all Jews in German-occupied Poland to wear the Star of David.
Russo-Finnish War Begins
After Helsinki rejects Moscow's territorial demands, the USSR invades Finland.
Russo-Finnish War Ends
After a gallant defense of their homeland, the Finns surrender to the USSR, losing extensive portions of their nation to their much larger neighbor.
German Invasion of Norway and Denmark
Breaking a seven-month lull in the European war, Germany strikes north and rapidly overruns Denmark. Fighting in Norway is tougher, and inspires British and French intervention.
Norwegian Resistance Collapses
After weeks of fighting, aided by Britain and France, Norway's defenders finally succumb to relentless Germany attacks.
German Offensive in the West
Ignoring declarations of neutrality, and intent on defeating France, Germany invades Belgium, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg on its way to the French frontier.
France and Britain Enter Belgium
The French and British ground forces enter Belgium to help defend the beleaguered kingdom against Germany.
Germans Cross Meuse
Crashing through the Ardennes region of France, Belgium, and Luxembourg, and bypassing the French defenses to the south (the famed Maginot Line), German forces cross the Meuse river.
Netherlands Surrenders
The Netherlands surrenders to Germany after the conquest of its major cities and the destruction of most of its armed forces.
Auschwitz Established
The most infamous of the Nazi death camps is established in Poland.
Belgium Surrenders
After nearly three weeks of desperate resistance, the Belgian government surrenders to the Germans.
British Evacuation from Dunkirk

Faced with the surrender of Belgium, and the disintegration of the French Army, Britain begins to evacuate its forces from the Continent. The week-long effort would end on June 4, and save a third of a million Allied troops, most of them British.
US Sends Arms to Britain

Shocked by the collapse of the Allied front in France, and worried about the survival of Great Britain, the US authorizes the release of large quantities of largely outdated military equipment to the British.
Russo-Japanese Accord
After years of conflict over Manchuria (Manchuko), Japan and Russia sign an agreement settling boundary disputes over the region.
Italy Enters the War
With a German victory in France virtually certain, Italy joins the war against the Allies, attacking into southern France.
Norwegian Government Flees

As the Norwegian military formally ended operations against the German invaders, the government fled to Britain to continue the war from abroad. A serious resistance movement begins inside Norway to oppose the German occupation.
Germans Occupy Paris
Continuing their destruction of the French Army, the Germans occupy the French capital.
USSR Occupies Baltic States
Taking advantage of the war in the west, the USSR occupies Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia on the Baltic coast.
France Surrenders

Six weeks after being invaded, France formally ends its war with Germany. The Germans take over 60% of the nation. The rest is a nominally independent--but in truth subordinate--rump state centered on the town of Vichy.
Britain Sinks French Warships

The British sink French warships in Algerian ports, out of concern that they would fall into the hands of the Germans, This action emphasizes the degree to which the Vichy French and the British are in opposition to each other.
US Expands Navy
In preparation for a possible two-ocean war, the US begins laying the ground work for an expanded navy capable of fighting in both the Atlantic and the Pacific.
Battle of Britain Begins

In preparation for a planned invasion of the British Isles, Germany begins extensive bombing of the United Kingdom. In a battle that will last three months, German aircraft pound British airfields, cities, and other strategic targets.
German Blockade of Britain
In an attempt to strangle the British Isles, Germany announces a total naval blockade of Britain, warning neutral shipping to steer clear.
US Trades Warships for British Bases
Working around American neutrality laws, the US offers dozens of old destroyers to Great Britain in exchange for use of British naval bases world wide.
Italy Invades Egypt
Attempting to expand its North African empire, Italy invades British-controlled Egypt but faces tough resistance.
US Introduces Conscription
For the first time in its history, the United States of America introduces peacetime conscription. The step is in reaction to the fall of France and the deteriorating world security situation.
Japan Occupies Indochina
Taking advantage of the diminished state of French power in Asia, Japan forces the Vichy government to allow Japanese forces access to airbases and facilities in the French Indochinese territories.
US Embargoes Scrap Metal Sales to Japan

Reacting to Japan's occupation of French Indochina, the American government embargoes the sale of scrap iron and steel to Japan, hoping to slow down its armaments industry. Lacking a strong steel industry of its own, Japan relies heavily on such imports.
Three-Power Pact

Japan, Germany, and Italy sign a mutual assistance treaty aimed in effect at the USSR and US. In the pact, the parties pledge mutual assistance if any of them is involved in conflict with a country that is not now a belligerent.
Germans Stop Issuing Visas for Polish Jews

Though relatively rare, exit visas for Jews left in German-occupied Poland had been available to a lucky few. Now, the German occupation government stops issuing them, thus trapping the remaining Jews.
Italy Invades Greece
Continuing its push for a Mediterranean empire, Italy launches an invasion of Greece from occupied Albania. The invasion is met with fierce resistance.
Battle of Britain Ends
Having failed to destroy the Royal Air Force and pave the way for a seaborne invasion of the British Isles, Germany calls off the air offensive known as the Battle of Britain.
Warsaw Ghetto Established
German authorities formally establish the Warsaw Ghetto; shortly thereafter, all Jews in Warsaw are not only forced to reside in the Ghetto, but are prohibited from leaving it.
Greek Offensive in Albania
After failing to dislodge the Greek defenders, Italy suffers a humiliating reversal as the Greek Army launches an offensive deep into Albania.
British Offensive in Egypt
Striking back at the invading Italians, the British forces in Egypt drive all the way into Libya, defeating large Italian forces on the way.
British Offensive in Libya
Furthering the see-saw battle in North Africa, the British and Commonwealth forces drive the Axis away from Egypt and back into Libya.
Germans Enter Italy
Due to military failures and the need to bolster Italian performance, Rome allows German military forces to move into Italy.
Romanian Anti-Jewish Riots

Romania demonstrates its sympathies with German racial policies as troops go on a rampage, killing hundreds of Jews and destroying Jewish property. Similar attitudes are prevalent in Slovakia and other Eastern European nations under German sway.
US Lend-Lease Act

In a further circumvention of the existing Neutrality Laws, Congress votes to allow the president to send military aid to nations deemed vital to American security. The result is millions in aid for Britain.
German Counteroffensive in Libya
With the dispatch of the Afrika Korps to aid the Italian forces in North Africa, Germany launches a counteroffensive that drives the British forces back to Egypt.
Germany Invades Greece and Yugoslavia
In an effort to wrap up the Italian "adventure" in the Balkans in time to free German forces for the upcoming invasion of Russia, Germany launches troops into Greece by way of Yugoslavia.
Belgrade Falls
German forces occupy the Yugoslav capital, but resistance forces spring up all over the Balkan nation, indicating that the people of Yugoslavia have not accepted German rule.
Russo-Japanese Treaty of Neutrality
Looking to secure its eastern flank, the USSR signs a treaty of neutrality with its Asian rival Japan.
Yugoslavia Surrenders
Yugoslavia formally surrenders to the invading Germans, though the nation remains a hotbed of partisan activity throughout the next four years.
Greece Surrenders
Greece capitulates in the face of overwhelming German military power. Despite aid from Britain and France, Greece was unable to stem the Axis advance.
State of Emergency Declared in US
Due to increased tension with Germany over U-boat attacks in the Atlantic, the US declares a state of emergency.
British and Free French Occupation of Syria
Attempting to stymie Axis designs on the Eastern Mediterranean, British and Free French forces battle Vichy French troops for control of Syria.
Vichy Calls for Arrest of All Jews
Vichy French authorities call for the administrative arrest of all Jews in France.
Germany Invades the USSR

In perhaps the largest military assault in history, Germany throws over three million men at the USSR in an attempt to destroy its arch-rival. The German forces overrun the unprepared Soviet defenders.
US Pledges Aid to USSR
Despite decades of anti-communist feeling in the US, the American government pledges aid to the USSR to defeat the German attack.
Red Friday
German forces go on rampages in Poland and the Russian city of Minsk, burning synagogues and murdering Jews.
China Severs Relations with Axis
In support of the Allied war effort, Nationalist China formally severs its relations with the European Axis powers.
Smolensk Falls
Crossing the pre-1939 Russian frontier, German forces capture the important Russian city of Smolensk as the Red Army continues to disintegrate.
Vichy Allows Japanese Occupation of French Indochina
Bowing to the inevitable, Vichy France allows the Japanese to occupy and control Indochina.
US Freezes Japanese Credits

Joining Britain in protesting the Japanese occupation of Indochina, the US freezes all Japanese trade credits. This brings trade between the two nations to a halt. Additionally, the Americans reorganize their Pacific command and warn the Japanese against any further aggressions.
Battle of the Atlantic
British estimates show that continued German submarine attacks have had a serious effect on Britain's ability to fight the war, and pose a serious threat to the island's survival.
Atlantic Charter

The leaders of the US and UK agree on what are essentially war aims, though the US is not officially at war. These aims include free trade, freedom of the seas, self-determination and a restoration of rights lost to aggression. Echoing Wilson's 14 Points from 1918, the Atlantic Charter would be the foundation of the Anglo-American alliance and the blueprint for post-war Europe.
US Extends Draft
The American president signs into law an extension of the conscription system approved in 1940.
Britain Pledges Aid to US in Event of War with Japan
Despite being hard-pressed, Britain promises to support the US if it gets into a war with Japan, as now seems increasingly likely.
Siege of Leningrad Begins
German forces begin the siege of Leningrad. Though the German forces are powerful, the Soviet city refuses to surrender.
German Submarine Attacks USS Greer
In the first overt action against American forces, a German U-boot attacks the American destroyer Greer, which is escorting merchant ships near Iceland.
US Orders Navy to Shoot German Subs on Sight
As the Battle of the Atlantic heats up, the technically neutral US orders its warships to shoot German submarines on sight.
US Begins Convoy Protection
To protect convoys heading to Britain, the US agrees to let its navy escort ships as far as Iceland.
German Offensive in USSR
Attempting to grab as much territory as possible before the Russian winter sets in, German forces drive deep into the Ukraine and western Russia. Kiev falls and Moscow is threatened.
Babi Yar
German forces massacre some 34,000 Jewish men, women, and children near the Ukrainian city of Kiev, with the cooperation of many local Ukrainians.
Moscow Conference

In the first three-way meeting of the Allied powers, the foreign ministers of the USSR, Britain, and the US meet in Moscow. Britain and the US reiterate their pledge for a "second front" in northwest Europe, and the USSR promises to enter the war against Japan after defeating Germany. The three could not agree on the status of the Polish government in exile or the potential post-war fate of Poland itself.
Battle of Moscow Begins

Marshalling a massive force, the Germans attempt to take the Soviet capital before the winter sets in. While coming within sight of the city, the Germans ultimately fail to capture it and are pushed back by a Soviet counterattack in December.
German Sub Sinks USS Reuben James
In the first casualty of the undeclared Atlantic war, the USS Reuben James is sunk by a German U-boat, with the loss of over 100 lives.
Jews Banished from Germany
Germany formally banishes all Jews and sends those few remaining in Germany to camps in the East.
US Extends Lend-Lease to USSR
The American government extends the Lend-Lease program to the Soviet Union, in order to bring more military aid to the beleaguered nation.
US Arms Merchant Ships
Further weakening the already diminished Neutrality Laws, Congress authorizes the arming of American merchant ships to fend off U-boat attacks.
US-Japan Negotiations
In an effort to prevent outright war between the US and Japan, representatives of the two nations meet in Washington throughout late November and early December.
Soviet Winter Offensive
Continuing its steamroller advance, the USSR drives deep into the northern section of the German line in Russia, reaching the pre-war Polish border by February.
Japan Attacks Pearl Harbor

Seeing negotiations as pointless, Japan strikes at the United States. With this attack, Japan hopes to remove American power from the flanks of a planned Japanese move into Southeast Asia. Though a tactical success, the attack brings the US into the war unified and desiring revenge. The Japanese also attack other US Pacific possessions and British forces in Hong Kong and elsewhere.
US Declares War on Japan
The United States, stung by the attacks on its Pacific forces, declares war on the Empire of Japan.
Japanese Taken into Custody in US
1200 Japanese-Americans are taken into custody by the FBI. No formal charges are made against them.
Japan Invades Philippines
Japanese forces land on the US possession of the Philippines, and begin a campaign to wrest the archipelago from American control.
Germany, Italy Declare War on US
True to their treaties with Japan, Berlin and Rome declare war on the United States. The war becomes a truly global conflict.
Britain Declares War on Japan
Following the Japanese attacks on Hong Kong and Malaya, Britain declares war on Japan.
Hong Kong Falls
The British colony of Hong Kong falls to Japan.
United Nations Formed

Though it would be years before it emerges as a true world forum, the United Nations is born as 26 nations sign the charter in Washington. The new organization is built on the foundation of the Anglo-American Atlantic Charter.
Japanese Campaign in Dutch East Indies
The Japanese begin their occupation of the Dutch East Indies, part of Tokyo's bid to control the resources of Southeast Asia. The campaign would last through March.
Wannsee Conference
German leaders meet outside Berlin and decide on a "final solution" to the Jewish "problem." They decide to murder the 11,000,000 European Jews as systematically and efficiently as possible.
Anglo-American War Council
The United States and Britain form a Combined Chiefs of Staff to better military cooperation.
Japan Invades Burma
Seeking to drive the British out of southern Asia, the Japanese begin an offensive aimed at Burma. It meets with initial success, prompting fears for the safety of British India.
Fall of Singapore
In the worst defeat ever for British arms, some 60,000 soldiers are captured as the Japanese take over the supposedly impregnable fortress of Singapore.
Japanese Offensive in New Guinea

Continuing its assault on the southern perimeter of its Asian empire, Japan invades New Guinea, precipitating a long and bloody struggle. Stiff Allied resistance prevents Japan from accomplishing its objectives in a campaign that would last for months.
Manzanar Internment Camp Opens
The first internment camp for Japanese-Americans opens. There will be 10 such camps, holding 120,000+ people. The last camp closes in 1946.
Japanese-Americans "Resettled"

In Seattle, the Army issues its first Civilian Exclusion Order, forcing Japanese residents to leave their homes. Within the next 7 months, nearly all Japanese-Americans living on the West coast would be moved to internment caps.
First Jews Deported from France to Auschwitz
The first trainload of Jews from occupied France departs for the death camp at Auschwitz, where new facilities including a huge crematorium are under construction.
Fall of Corregidor
After months of combat, the last American stronghold in the Philippines falls to the Japanese.
Battle of the Coral Sea
In the first true defeat of the Japanese in WWII, Allied forces led by the US Navy defeat a Japanese attempt to land troops in Australia and the New Hebrides.
Anglo-Soviet Aid Treaty
Britain and the USSR sign a 20-year mutual aid treaty.
Axis Offensive in North Africa
Reinvigorated with new troops and supplies, the Axis forces in Libya, led by the German Afrika Korps, drive deep into Egypt and press back the Commonwealth defenders.
First 1000 Plane Raid on Cologne

Marshalling 1000 bombers for the first time against one target, the Royal Air Force pounds the German city of Cologne. This presages the strategic bombing campaign against German cities that the US and Britain will mount for the rest of the war.
Battle of Midway Begins

In a four-day encounter, the US Navy smashes a Japanese invasion force headed for the US owned island of Midway, in the north Pacific. Japan loses four aircraft carriers and many skilled pilots, while American losses are far fewer.
German Summer Offensive in the USSR

Beginning a massive attack that would continue for the next three months, German forces drive deep into southern Russia and the Ukraine. Eventually, by September, the Germans reach the Volga river and the important Soviet city of Stalingrad.
Japan Invades Aleutians

Attempting to seize a foothold in North America, and distract American forces from Japanese efforts in Southeast Asia, Japan invades the Aleutian Islands off of Alaska. The ensuing campaign is a bitter struggle in terrible conditions, which the Japanese ultimately lose.
US Defense Spending hits $42 Billion
The US Congress allocates $42 billion to fight the war, marking the largest defense appropriation in US history.
Treblinka II Opens
The second phase of the Treblinka concentration camp opens, dedicated entirely to the extermination of Jews. It would be the final destination of many from the Warsaw ghetto.
Guadalcanal Campaign

Striking back at the Japanese, the US lands troops on Guadalcanal and other points in the Solomon Islands. Fighting would continue into February of 1943 before the Japanese would be forced to evacuate the region.
Manhattan Project
Capitalizing on earlier research and preparation, the US government authorizes the start of a massive engineering project to create an atomic weapon.
Soviet Counteroffensive
Taking advantage of the overextended German lines, the USSR launches a giant counterattack against the German summer offensive. As a result, German troops are surrounded at Stalingrad.
Battle of El Alamein

With new leadership and more logistical support than in the past, the British and Commonwealth forces launce major attacks against the Axis forces in Egypt and Libya, driving them back and capturing important locations like Tobruk and Tripoli.
Allies Invade French North Africa

In the US's first ground assault in the European Theater of Operations, American and British forces assault Vichy-held North Africa. Landing in Morocco and Algeria, the Allied forces soon move into Tunisia, precipitating a long campaign that would end only in the spring of 1943 with the Axis surrender in North Africa.
Vichy North Africa Joins Allies
Signing an armistice to end the fighting in French North Africa, the Vichy authorities there join with the Allies in opposition to Germany.
Germany Occupies Vichy France
Angered over the shift of Vichy North Africa into the Allied camp, Germany occupies the remainder of France, which had been under the nominal control of the Vichy government.
First Self-Sustaining Atomic Reaction

Scientists working on the atomic bomb project manage to create the world's first self-sustaining atomic reaction, at the University of Chicago. This demonstrated that an atomic weapon was a real possibility.
Casablanca Conference

The leaders of the US, Britain, and Free France meet in Morocco and demand "unconditional surrender" from the Axis forces. They also agree on the need for a full-scale invasion of occupied Europe in the near future.
Relief of Leningrad
After a year and a half of siege, Leningrad is liberated by the Red Army.
First US Bombing Raid on Germany
For the first time, United States aircraft mount a bombing raid on German territory, hitting the city of Wilhelmshaven.
Clearing of Stalingrad
Following months of bitter fighting, the USSR forces the surrender of nearly 100,000 Axis troops in and around the city of Stalingrad.
Kasserine Pass
Striking back against the American and British forces encircling Tunisia, the German Afrika Korps launches a devastating attack against the American forces threatening Tunis.
German Offensive in Russia
The Germans in the Ukraine and southern Russia strike back at the advancing Soviets, retaking some ground but overall being pushed back by superior Russian forces.
Warsaw Ghetto Uprising

Jews in the Warsaw ghetto oppose a German incursion with force. The bloody struggle lasts until May 8, when Germans use poison gas to kill the last Jewish defenders. Even then, pockets of resistance hold out for days.
Axis Surrenders in Tunisia
A quarter of a million Axis troops surrender as the British and American forces take Tunis on May 7th and secure Tunisia.
Trident Conference

American and British leaders meet in Washington. There they plan the invasions of Sicily and Italy as the next steps in the war in the Mediterranean. They also agree on the timing for an invasion of occupied Europe--a second front against the Nazis.
Warsaw Ghetto Destroyed
After weeks of violence, the Germans finish systematically destroying the Warsaw ghetto, ending with the blowing up of the synagogue.
French Government in Exile Formed
Formalizing what had grown into a de facto entity, the Free French form a government in exile in Algiers.
Allied South Pacific Offensive
Led by the Americans, the Allies kick off a six-month drive through the South Pacific as the war against Japan continues.
Battle of Kursk

The Germans launch a major offensive to destroy a large Soviet force around the Russian city of Kursk. The month-long struggle ends in a draw, but with the cream of the German army badly battered. This is the last major offensive the Germans will launch in the East.
Invasion of Sicily

Following the designs laid down by the Allied leaders, American and British forces invade Sicily, as a stepping stone to the European mainland. The operation is successful, though incomplete, as many German troops manage to escape the island.
Italian Leader Resigns
Faced with the loss of North Africa and Sicily, and beset with growing war-weariness at home, the Italian dictator resigns, and is immediately placed under arrest.
Soviet Summer Offensive

As the Germans struggle against the Anglo-American invasion of France, the USSR launches a massive attack against Germany's eastern front. Reaching East Prussia and moving into Poland and Romania, the USSR destroys massive numbers of German troops.
First Quebec Conference
The US and Britain reaffirm their intention to invade northwest Europe in 1944, and discuss other aspects of the ongoing world war.
Allied Offensive in SE Asia
Driving from India, a mainly British Allied force pushes into Japanese-held Burma. The Allies aim to restore critical supply routes to China.
Invasion of Italy
Continuing their step by step march across the southern flank of Europe, the Allies invade southern Italy and begin the drive on Rome.
Italy Surrenders

Though the Italian government had signed an armistice on September 3, the actual surrender to the Allied forces took place six days later. Germany immediately occupied as much of Italy as possible and prepared to defend the area against the Allied attack.
Italy Declares War on Germany
The new government of Italy, having rid itself of its association with Germany, declares war on its former ally, Most of Italy is occupied by the Germans, with the rest occupied by the Allies.
Central Pacific Offensive
Focusing on the Marshall Islands, American forces continue their drive to push the Japanese out of their south Pacific possessions.
Tehran Conference

For the first time, the leaders of the US, USSR, and Britain meet face to face, in Tehran. They agree on the joint occupation and protection of Iran, the details of the upcoming invasion of France, and the timing of the simultaneous Soviet spring offensive.
Cairo Declaration

The leaders of the US, Britain, and China lay out their goals for the war against Japan, including unconditional surrender by Tokyo, and a pledge that none of the Allies would seek territorial expansion.
Anzio Landings

In an attempt to break the stalemate in southern Italy, Allied forces land troops just south of Rome at the town of Anzio. The landing, which was supposed to result in a lightning thrust at the Italian capital, bogs down instead.
Korsun Pocket

The USSR launches a massive assault on German forces near the Ukrainian city of Korsun. The Soviets surround and destroy a large Axis force by late March. Further drives to the south result in Soviet control of the Crimea by May.
Germany Occupies Hungary
To stem Soviet progress, Germany occupies its ally Hungary and takes control of the Eastern European nation.
Hungarian Deportations Begin
The first group of Jews leaves Hungary for the death camps. By late May, 12,000 Jews would be shipped to Birkenau a day.
Allied Burma Offensive
After bitter fighting, the British manage to secure northern Burma and resume supply flights to China.
Fall of Rome

After bitter fighting, Allied forces clear the fortress of Monte Cassino and open the road to Rome. The fall of the Italian capital, while symbolic, has little effect on the overall war in Italy, as the Germans continue to offer strong resistance.
Allies Invade France
Allied forces storm ashore in Normandy, to secure a beachhead in occupied northwest Europe. This long-awaited "second front" is the beginning of the final drive to destroy German power in the west.
Battle of Saipan

Driving ever northward, the Allied forces in the Central Pacific launch attacks on the Mariana Islands, focusing on the large Japanese island of Saipan. Ferocious resistance including the mass suicide of civilians gives a hint of the struggles to come as the Americans get closer to Japan itself.
Hungarian Deportations Stop
With the war going badly, and under rare pressure from other nations, Germany halts the deportation of Jews from Hungary. 437,000 Hungarian Jews had already been shipped to the death camps.
Failed Attempt to Kill German Leader
A group of German officers fail in their attempt to kill their dictatorial leader with a bomb.
Allied Breakout in France
After a month of stalemate in Normandy, the Allied forces break out of their beachhead and begin chasing the Germans out of northern France.
Paris Falls, Deportations Continue
Despite the onrushing Allied armies and the collapse of the Germany military in the west, Germany continues to ship French Jews to death camps.
Polish Uprising

As the Soviet army drives through Poland, Polish forces rise up against the German occupation. Soviet and Polish forces do not unite. The USSR is near Warsaw by September, but it does not invade the city until January 1945.
Lodz Ghetto Deportations Begin
Germany begins deporting the largest group of Jews left in Europe, the nearly 70,000 in the Lodz ghetto. They are sent to Birkenau to be gassed.
Japan Expelled from India
British forces expel the last Japanese troops from India, securing the colony.
Invasion of Southern France
Completing the one-two punch planned months previously, Allied forces land on the Mediterranean coast of France in an effort to outflank German defenses.
Dumbarton Oaks Conference

Meeting in Washington, DC, representatives from the Allied powers discuss the new United Nations, and try to agree on a formal charter. Unresolved differences presage rising tensions to come after the war ends.
Paris Falls to Allies
More than four years after the Germans took the "City of Lights," Free French forces liberate the French capital.
Romania Declares War on Axis
After being overrun and occupied by the USSR, Romania switches sides and declares war on the Axis.
Allied Offensive in France
In a three-month offensive, the Allies in France drive to the borders of Germany, and into Belgium and the Netherlands.
USSR Declares War on Bulgaria
Eager to knock another Axis power out of the war, the USSR declares war on Bulgaria, even though Bulgaria has not participated in the fighting against the Soviets.
First V-2 Attacks
For the first time in history, ballistic rockets are used to attack an enemy as the Germans launch their V-2 missiles at England.
Second Quebec Conference
The leaders of the US and Britain meet in Canada to discuss the post-war world, in particular the division and occupation of Germany.
Allied Offensive in the Netherlands

Boldly attempting to outflank German defenses in the west, the British lead an Allied airborne assault over a series of rivers in the Netherlands. Though partially successful, the attack fails in its attempt to run armored forces around Germany's northern flank.
Soviet Baltic Offensive
The USSR continues its drive west, clearing the Baltic states of German forces and moving up to the border of East Prussia.
Allied Invasion of Greece
British forces land in Greece and rapidly liberate the country from Axis control.
Second Moscow Conference

British and Soviet leaders meet in Moscow to discuss Poland and the Balkans. The two sides agree on a split of "spheres of influence" in the Balkans, and on the borders of Poland. Not present at the talks, the leader of the US disavows these agreements.
US Invasion of the Philippines
Returning to the archipelago nearly three years after the Japanese attack, American forces invade the Philippines, starting a campaign that would last up until June of 1945.
USSR Captures Belgrade
Aided by the efforts of partisans, the Red Army occupies the Yugoslav capital.
Allies Recognize Provisional French Government
The Allies formally recognize the Free French as the legitimate government of France.
Birkenau Gas Chamber Shuts Down
As the USSR closes in, Germany shuts down the gas chambers at Birkenau and begins destroying evidence of mass murder.
Battle of Budapest Begins
In a battle that would last until mid-February 1945, the USSR begins an assault on the Hungarian capital.
Franco-Soviet Treaty
The newly-recognized French government signs a 20-year treaty with the USSR.
Battle of the Bulge

In a last-gasp attempt to regain the initiative in the west, the Germans launch a massive attack against a "bulge" in the Allied line in Belgium. Despite initial success, the Allies drive back the attackers, with devastating losses to the German forces.
USSR Captures Warsaw
As part of its massive offensive into Poland, the USSR captures the Polish capital.
Death Marches Begin
With less than 60,000 Jews left in death camps, Germany marches prisoners away from the onrushing Soviet armies.
Birkenau Liberated
The Red Army rolls into the near-deserted Birkenau. Though the Germans had destroyed or removed much of the evidence of the mass murders they committed there, much still remains.
Malta Conference

The leaders of Britain and the US meet to discuss the ongoing campaign against Germany. The focus of the conference, however, shifts to the fears of growing Soviet power and the undesirability of a Soviet campaign deep into central Europe.
Yalta Conference

The leaders of the three major Allied powers meet in the Crimean town of Yalta to discuss the post-war world. The US, Britain, and the USSR agree on the border of Poland and the idea of free elections in eastern Europe. The USSR also agrees to join the war against Japan within 3 months after Germany surrenders.
Allied Offensive in the West
Beginning the final push into Germany, Allied forces launch a major offensive into the Netherlands and Germany, eventually crossing the Rhine and driving deep into German territory.
Invasion of Iwo Jima
Moving ever closer to Japan, the Americans invade Iwo Jima, a volcanic island some 750 miles from Tokyo. Bitter fighting lasts until the middle of March, when the Japanese are defeated.
Battle of Okinawa

Finally landing on Japanese soil, American forces initiate a bitter fight to gain this island as a forward airbase. Fierce resistance includes suicide attacks by Japanese fliers. Casualties are high on both sides.
USSR Denounces Pact with Japan
Preparing to honor the agreement made at Yalta, USSR abrogates its non-aggression pact with Japan.
American Leader Dies
Franklin D. Roosevelt, the American President, dies from a long illness. His successor, Harry S. Truman, is committed to following the same policies for the war effort.
Battle of Berlin
Culminating four years of bloody struggle, the USSR begins its assault on the German capital.
British Liberate Belsen
British forces liberate the concentration camp at Belsen. Despite medical efforts, hundreds of former prisoners continue to die each day from disease and malnutrition.
Allied Offensive in Italy
Breaking through tough German resistance, Allied forces liberate northern Italy and eventually link up with American forces in Austria.
US Forces Liberate Dachau
American troops liberate the German concentration camp at Dachau.
Germans in Italy Surrender
The last German forces in Italy surrender to Allied troops.
German Leader Dies
Surrounded by Soviet troops converging on the center of the German government, German Chancellor Adolf Hitler commits suicide in Berlin, leaving the nation in chaos.
German Forces Surrender in Denmark, the Netherlands
German forces in the Netherlands, Denmark, and parts of northern Germany surrender to the western Allies.
US Forces Enter Mauthausen
American forces liberate the Mauthausen concentration camp, and find thousands of bodies in communal graves.
Germany Surrenders

Ending the European war, Germany agrees to an unconditional surrender to Allied forces. The next day, May 8th, is officially deemed "Victory in Europe" day, though the surrender itself would not be ratified until May 9th.
V-E Day
Victory in Europe (V-E) day is the day after Germany agrees to an unconditional surrender, and the day before the surrender is officially ratified.
Creation of the Austrian Republic

Despite the Soviet desire to treat Austria as a defeated nation, the western Allies define it as a liberated country. As such, Britain and the US help establish a democratic republic in their occupation zones. Meanwhile, the USSR extracts reparations from the zone of Austria under its power.
Division of Germany
Representatives of the Allied powers formally divide Germany into four sections, or zones, controlled by the USSR, the US, Britain, and France. Berlin is also divided into four parts.
Polish Government Formed
A pro-Soviet government is formed from parts of competing Polish political groups, and recognized by the Allies.
Occupation of Berlin
The Americans, British, and Russians agree on a three way (later four-way) division of the German capital city, replacing the USSR's sole occupation.
Atomic Bomb Tested
At Alamogordo, New Mexico, the US successfully detonates an atomic weapon, ushering in the atomic age. The intent is to rush bombs into production to use against Japan.
Potsdam Conference

The leaders of the US, USSR, and Britain meet outside the German capital to discuss post-war Germany and the ongoing war in the Pacific. Decisions made include disarming Germany, war crimes trials, and adjudicating reparations.
Allies Demand Japan Surrenders
Following the ideas established in the Cairo Conference and the recent Potsdam Conference, the Allied powers demanded the unconditional surrender of Japan. On July 29th, Japan refused this demand.
New Leader in Britain
Elections in Britain result in a new leader. The transition is peaceful and has little effect on ongoing diplomacy.

Unwilling to undertake a bloody invasion of the Japanese home islands, and unable to convince the Japanese to surrender, the United States drops the first atomic bomb on the city of Hiroshima. Half the city is destroyed in an instant.
USSR Declares War on Japan
The Soviet Union declares war on Japan, keeping its agreement to join its Allies against Japan. The USSR begins military operations in Manchuria (Manchuko).
After failing to agree on surrender terms, the US drops a second atomic weapon on Nagasaki.
Japan Surrenders

Convinced by the two atomic bombs that Japan can no longer resist the Allied attack, Japan's leaders surrender. The surrender is unconditional--the only exception is that the Japanese are allowed to keep their Emperor as a figurehead.
V-J Day
August 15th is declared the official end of the war against Japan.
USSR Occupies Manchuria
The USSR occupies Manchuria, the Chinese territory that was under Japanese rule (as Manchuko) for 14 years.
US Occupation of Japan
The US lands troops in Japan to begin its occupation of the defeated nation.
Formal Japanese Surrender
Aboard a US warship in Tokyo Bay, the Japanese officially surrender, thus ending WWII.
Council of Ministers Meeting
Meeting in London for the first time, the new Council of Ministers formed by the former Allies fails to resolve post-war issues. A growing tension is apparent between the West and the USSR.
United Nations Opens
After 29 nations ratify its charter, the United Nations officially opens.
Nuremburg Trials
War crimes trials begin in the German city of Nuremburg. The trials, which will last nearly a year, seek to punish Germans guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity.
US Joins United Nations
Rejecting the neutrality that it adopted after the First World War, the US joins the United Nations.
Allied Occupation of Korea

Although they had agreed to create a provisional Korean government, neither the western Allies, China, or the USSR could agree on what that government should be. Therefore, Korea remains divided at the 38th parallel, with the USSR in the North and the US in the south.
